questions.question_text: A security analyst is performing a manual audit of captured data from a packet analyzer. The analyst looks for Base64 encoded strings and applies the filter http.authbasic. Which of the following BEST describes what the analyst is looking for?

choices.B: Denial of service due to an integrated legacy operating system.
choices.A: Repeated exploitation due to unpatchable firmware
choices.E: Exhaustion of network resources resulting from poor NIC management.
choices.D: Key reuse and collision issues due to decentralized management.
choices.C: Loss of inventory accountability due to device deployment

questions.question_text: Which of the following impacts are associated with vulnerabilities in embedded systems? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: im sorry what
Shouldn't the log files be read-only for the system changers... read-only for the auditors are dumb.
Donâ€™t over think it, Admins usually perform changes, and it says â€˜individualsâ€™ so thereâ€™s more than one person performing each job thus we need groups. A is correct

Always assign permissions via groups. 

Answer A

comments.content: Valid point. I did lean with A but your explanation makes sense. Just because they have permission to conduct system changes, doesn't necessarily mean they are called "administrators". That's a tricky wordplay here.
"Individuals" is plural, so there's multiple people who make changes and other audit them. A is correct, because you should assign permission to groups then add the appropriate users to them.
Aren't you the one who submitted the question?

discussion.content: D sounds better. The question says individuals twice. It doesn't mention administrators. Scrap the whole group thing and give individual permission to files.

questions.question_text:
An organization wants to separate permissions for individuals who perform system changes from individuals who perform auditing of those system changes.
Which of the following access control approaches is BEST suited for this?

choices.C: Create two groups and ensure each group has representation from both the auditors and the administrators so they can verify any changes that were made.
choices.D: Assign file and folder permissions on an individual user basis and avoid group assignment altogether.
choices.A: Assign administrators and auditors to different groups and restrict permissions on system log files to read-only for the auditor group.
choices.B: Assign administrators and auditors to the same group, but ensure they have different permissions based on the function they perform.

comments.content: Your explanation clears up all my doubts, thank you!
Also 'functioning as expected' implies you are looking back on previous history and seeing how successful you were. So Authentication & Authorization don't make sense.

discussion.content: "functioning as expected" - you are doing an accounting of it and auditing it to make sure all is good.
B and D?
